title: 1999 Belarusian Premier League
text:
The 1999 <a href="Belarusian%20Premier%20League">Belarusian Premier League</a> was the ninth season of top-tier <a href="Association%20football">football</a> in <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a>. It started on April 11 and ended on October 30, 1999. <a href="FC%20Dnepr%20Mogilev">Dnepr-Transmash Mogilev</a> were the defending champions.
Team changes from 1998 season.
<a href="FC%20Dinamo-93%20Minsk">Dinamo-93 Minsk</a> dissolved midway through 1998 season and <a href="FC%20Kommunalnik%20Slonim">FC Kommunalnik Slonim</a> relegated to the <a href="Belarusian%20First%20League">First League</a> after finishing in the last place. They were replaced by <a href="1998%20Belarusian%20First%20League">1998 First League</a> winners <a href="FC%20Lida">Lida</a>, who previously played in Premier League as Obuvshchik Lida, and the newcomers <a href="FC%20Osipovichi">Svisloch-Krovlya Osipovichi</a>, First League runners-up. Torpedo Minsk changed their name to <a href="FC%20Torpedo%20Minsk">Torpedo-MAZ Minsk</a> and Neman Grodno were renamed to <a href="FC%20Neman%20Grodno">Neman-Belcard Grodno</a>.
Overview.
<a href="FC%20BATE%20Borisov">BATE Borisov</a> won their 1st champions title and qualified for the next season's Champions League. The championship runners-up and <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20Belarusian%20Cup">1999–2000 Cup</a> winners <a href="FC%20Slavia%20Mozyr">Slavia Mozyr</a> as well as bronze medalists <a href="FC%20Gomel">Gomel</a> qualified for UEFA Cup. Newcomers <a href="FC%20Osipovichi">Svisloch-Krovlya Osipovichi</a> finished their first and the only season in top league in 15th place and relegated, as did 16th team <a href="FC%20Molodechno">Molodechno</a>.
